paper_metadata.title: Diagnosis and Treatment of Hereditary Transthyretin Amyloidosis (hATTR) Polyneuropathy: Current Perspectives on Improving Patient Care
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted genetic variant information for the TTR gene, including penetrance data.

patients.demographics: Various, including endemic regions such as Portugal, Japan, and Sweden

individual_records.evidence_sentence: Patients from endemic areas have traditionally been described as having an early-onset (age <50 years) or late-onset disease.
Late-onset Val30Met patients have usually a more rapid and severe progression.
In non-endemic areas, incomplete penetrance that constantly increases with age is commonly seen.

functional_data.summary: The Val30Met mutation leads to reduced stability of TTR tetramers, enhancing their dissociation into monomers.

variants.segregation_data: Segregates with disease in families, especially in endemic regions.
variants.population_frequency: Common in endemic regions, particularly in Portugal.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on multiple studies and family segregation.
variants.additional_notes: The Val30Met mutation is the most common pathogenic variant associated with hATTR.
key_quotes: The most common pathogenic variant consists of a point mutation leading to replacement of valine by methionine at position 30 of the mature protein.
A complete penetrance has often been described in multi-generation pedigrees from endemic areas.

individual_records.evidence_sentence: Patients with Val122Ile often present with cardiac involvement.
Incomplete penetrance that constantly increases with age is commonly seen.

functional_data.summary: The Val122Ile mutation is associated with a predominantly cardiac phenotype.

variants.population_frequency: Less common than Val30Met but significant in the USA.
variants.evidence_level: Moderate evidence based on clinical observations.
variants.additional_notes: Associated with a higher risk of cardiac symptoms.
key_quotes: Some variants typically manifest with a predominant or isolated cardiomyopathy.
Patients carrying homozygous pathogenic mutations have also been reported.

tables_processed.table_caption: Clinical Manifestations and Epidemiology of the Most Common hATTR Mutations

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data was extracted from the main text and tables.
